channel.title: Old School Client Loader V2
channel.description:
Hate using the webclient? Don't want to download a 50mb+ external client? I introduce to you my Old School Client Loader!
[ul][li]Light weight - no useless garbage included[/li] [li]Animated loading GIF[/li] [li]Silab's "never full world" implementation[/li] [li]Open source[/li][/ul]
[img width=1080 height=675]http://i.imgur.com/BOTxYJ7.jpg[/img] [img width=1080 height=675]http://i.imgur.com/OUU9nxM.jpg[/img] [img width=1080 height=675]http://i.imgur.com/8M4K1DB.jpg[/img]
Download (source included): http://up.ht/14dcpnT

item.title: Old School Client Loader V2
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

I’ll paste something i found on the internet to explain it a little better than i could,

Using the default package may create namespace collisions. Imagine you're creating a library which contains a [i]MyClass[/i] class. Someone uses your library in his project and also has a MyClass class in his default package. What should the compiler do? Package in Java is actually a namespace which fully identifies your project. So it's important to not use the default package in the real world projects.

Read full topic

ono, please, don’t ever ever ever ever use the default package. I have a more secure loader i’m releasing tonight too. I can add little things like this in if you guys really want it.

item.title: Old School Client Loader V2
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=".S. v2, post:44, topic:495616"][quote author=Ruby link=topic=613848.msg4239847#msg4239847 date=1361758866]
This is literally no different to loading it through your browser.
[/quote]

I don’t believe you know Java or the Applet related API. What makes you think you know that?

Yes, it is different.

They could see that the necessary resources are not being loaded by analysing HTTP access logs.

They could see that the User Agent (or other HTTP request properties) are not similar to most popular web browsers.

They could see that when the client requests for a document to be shown it just crashes because of the RuntimeException. I believe it sends a showDocument request when an error occurs.

They could see that it does not declare the applet to be inactive when it is expected to be inactive (imthenull: Please read the documentation for isActive. It should never always return true.)

An applet is active just before its start method is called.

Therefore the code should be something like this:

applet.init(); stub.setActive(true); applet.start();[/quote]
Thanks for the info. I didn’t know some of that, I will try to make use of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Old School Client Loader V2
item.dc:creator: @S_v2 .S. v2
item.description:
@S_v2 wrote:

Ruby:

This is literally no different to loading it through your browser.

I don’t believe you know Java or the Applet related API. What makes you think you know that?

Yes, it is different.

They could see that the necessary resources are not being loaded by analysing HTTP access logs.

They could see that the User Agent (or other HTTP request properties) are not similar to most popular web browsers.

They could see that when the client requests for a document to be shown it just crashes because of the RuntimeException. I believe it sends a showDocument request when an error occurs.

They could see that it does not declare the applet to be inactive when it is expected to be inactive (imthenull: Please read the documentation for isActive. It should never always return true.)

An applet is active [b]just before[/b] its start method is called.

Therefore the code should be something like this:

applet.init(); stub.setActive(true); applet.start();

Read full topic

item.title: Old School Client Loader V2
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:41, topic:495616”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=613848.msg4239942#msg4239942 date=1361764075]
I feel retarded, I can’t get it to fullscreen while keeping the same resolution. It would be nice to be zoomed-in. I’m used to using Slick or LWJGL so I have no idea how to do it with an Applet.
[/quote]
have you tried toying around with the graphics environment?[/quote]
yeah, but the GE/GD requires a Window not an Applet (i.e. JFrame). I tried changing the resolution of the JFrame but it had some… odd effects and was not functional at all…

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:42, topic:495616”]How would we be able to expand the games size? ;o

Expanding the frame’s is easy.[/quote]
What I’m aiming for is changing the monitor’s resolution to 765x503 while making the application fullscreen, similar to a method Maplestory uses. I know how to do this using LWJGL or Slick but not the JDK :C

Edit: Here’s the general idea, though I had to change my screen resolution to achieve this. It’s as large as my 21.5" monitor, the pic is a pretty poor representation.

Read full topic
